Award.AwardTitle: A Least-Squares Fit of an Ocean Model to Deglacial Radiocarbon Records
Award.AbstractNarration:
The deep ocean is renewed, or "ventilated", when surface waters present at high latitudes become sufficiently cold and very dense. These waters subsequently spread laterally, filling the various deep oceanic basins, and eventually return to the sea surface. Ventilation is therefore the very process by which the deep ocean communicates with our atmosphere and as such, is thought to play a particularly important role in the climate system. This project will estimate the changes in deep ocean ventilation which took place during the last deglaciation -- the largest manifestation of natural climate change that remains relatively well preserved in the geologic record. It will (i) promote the progress of science by elucidating the contribution of ocean ventilation changes to the deglacial rise in atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) observed in ice cores, (ii) be profitable to the broader scientific community by making freely available the computer codes developed for this project, (iii) support education by engaging three students and by drafting a little pocket book on the methods used for this project and aimed particularly at undergraduate and graduate students, and (iv) benefit society by furthering understanding of the ocean's role in the natural changes of atmospheric CO2 -- the most important greenhouse gas in our atmosphere after water vapor and the subject of major current environmental and societal concerns.

In more technical terms, the history of the ventilation of deep oceanic basins over the past 20,000 yr will be estimated from the quantitative combination of ocean radiocarbon (14C) records with an ocean circulation model using recursive least-squares techniques (a Kalman filter and a related smoother). The challenge posed by the application of these powerful but computationally intensive techniques over geologic time scales will be addressed by using a coarse-resolution model with simplified dynamics in concert with efficient filtering and smoothing algorithms. The hypothesis that ocean ventilation changes contributed to the changes in atmospheric CO2 concentration of the last deglaciation will be tested with due regard for the uncertainties and sparse distribution of the radiocarbon records. The work plan of this research will comprise four tasks. (1) An ocean circulation model of intermediate complexity, based on coarse resolution and planetary geostrophy, will be applied. It will have a grid that accommodates the spatial distribution of 14C records and include a simplified sea-ice model and transport equation for 14C. (2) Modern and paleo-data, including more than 1000 14C age estimates from benthic foraminifera and deep-sea corals, will be assembled together with uncertainty estimates. (3) A Kalman filter will be used to combine the model with the data during a forward integration of the model from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to today. (4) A smoother will be used to propagate backwards in time the information provided by the data (including modern data) and hence further constrain past ocean states. From (3-4), an estimate of basin-scale ocean ventilation rates from LGM to today will be derived, one that is consistent with the data and the model, given estimates of their respective error statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The deep ocean is renewed, or "ventilated", when surface waters present at high latitudes become sufficiently cold and dense to sink. These waters then spread laterally, filling the various deep oceanic basins, and eventually return to the sea surface. Ventilation is therefore the process by which the deep ocean communicates with the surface ocean and hence with the atmosphere. Accordingly, it plays an important role in the climate system. For example, the oceanic uptake of carbon dioxide and heat excesses in the atmosphere that are associated with the combustion of fossil fuel and other human activities, are largely the result of the ventilation process.

Among the "tracers" of deep ocean ventilation is radiocarbon. Radiocarbon is an unstable isotope that is produced in the atmosphere from the interaction of cosmic rays with atmospheric constituents. Radiocarbon is then oxidized to carbon dioxide, which is taken up by plants during photosynthesis and is dissolved in ocean surface waters. Once radiocarbon enters the ocean, it can be transported to abyssal depths along with dense waters that sink at high northern and southern latitudes. At abyssal depths, radiocarbon decays radioactively to an extent that depends on its residence time in the deep sea. These considerations have led to the widespread use of radiocarbon, sometimes in conjunction with other tracers, to infer quantitative measures of the ventilation of deep oceanic basins. Similar considerations have prompted paleoceanographers to use radiocarbon measurements on fossil biogenic carbonates, mostly benthic foraminifera and deep-sea corals, sampled from the sediment cores and the seafloor, to estimate deep ocean ventilation in the geologic past, particularly during periods of past climate change.

In this project, measurements of the radiocarbon concentration in fossil biogenic carbonates have been used to study the ventilation of the deep Atlantic Ocean during the last deglaciation - the most recent transition of the Earth's climate from a glacial state to an interglacial state. Our work included three main steps. First, fossil radiocarbon data generated over the past three decades in different research laboratories have been compiled into a coherent dataset. Second, the ventilation rate of deep layers in the modern Atlantic has been estimated by combining hydrographic observations with an ocean circulation model. Finally, the consistency of the fossil data with the modern ventilation rates has been determined using methods of data analysis that allow both data and model errors to be considered (inverse methods).

Our major results are the following:

1) The majority, not all, of fossil radiocarbon data for the deep Atlantic and the last deglacial period appear consistent with modern ventilation, when data and model errors are considered. This result tends to contrast with the widely held notion, based on analyses of radiocarbon data that do not consider model errors, that the deep Atlantic, both in the southern and northern hemispheres, was subjected to increased ventilation during the last deglacial period.

2) Whist fossil data were found to be generally compatible with modern ventilation, a significant fraction of them, from 19 to 40%, appear inconsistent with modern ventilation rates in the deep Atlantic. Noticeably, fossil data from below 4000 m in the western North Atlantic were found to be systematically lower than expected from modern ventilation rates. This result suggests that increased ventilation of deep waters did occur in the western North Atlantic during the last deglaciation, thereby contributing to the decrease in radiocarbon concentration and the increase in carbon dioxide concentration in the deglacial atmosphere that have been reconstructed from paleoclimatic archives.

Overall, this project has illustrated the great potential of the methods of data analysis that have been applied for the rigorous interpretation of deep-water paleoceanographic indicators obtained from sediment cores and deep-sea corals.

Broader Impacts: 1) This project has involved the collaboration of two scientists with different academic background and research experience. 2) It has supported the research of a graduate student from the MIT-WHOI Joint Program in Oceanography. 3) It has provided the opportunity to the Principal Investigator for teaching rudiments of inverse methods to students, post-doctoral researchers, and faculty members at the University of California in Santa Cruz. 4) The dataset assembled for this project has been submitted to the National Centers for Environmental Information of the NOAA in order to make it freely available to the public. 5) The results from this project have been disseminated at conferences and at a workshop, and they have been reported in two manuscripts submitted to a peer-reviewed journal. 6) The methods of analysis that have been developed for this project could be applied in other scientific disciplines and in engineering. These methods have been described in detail in a manuscript submitted to a peer-reviewed journal and will be made available to the community upon publication.
